title: F statistic
text: By the null hypothesis that the variances are the same, let s denote the standard deviations. The F statistic is $$\frac{{s_1}^2}{{s_2}^2}$$.

title: F statistic
text: Suppose we sample randomly from two independent normal populations. Let $$\sigma**{2}_{1} $$and$$ $$\sigma**{2}_{2} $$be$$ $$the$$ $$population$$ $$variances$$ $$and$$ $$s**{2}_{1} $$and$$ $$s**{2}_{1} $$be$$ $$the$$ $$sample$$ $$variances$$. $$Let$$ $$the$$ $$sample$$ $$sizes$$ $$be$$ $$n_1$$ $$and$$. $$_2$$. $$Since$$ $$we$$ $$are$$ $$interested$$ $$in$$ $$comparing$$ $$the$$ $$two$$ $$sample$$ $$variances$$, $$we$$ $$use$$ $$the$$ $$F$$ $$ratio$$: $$F$$ $$=$$ \dfrac{\left[\dfrac{(s_{1})**{2}}{(\sigma_{1})**{2}}\right]}{\left[\dfrac{(s_{2})**{2}}{(\sigma_{2})**{2}}\right]}

title: F statistic
text: Given the variances, we can take the square root of each of them to find the standard deviation, and thereafterwards divide them by each other to get our F statistic.
speech: Given the variances, we can take the square root of each of them to find the standard deviation, and thereafterwards divide them by each other to get our F statistic.
